title: This player has trolled every game for a week and still hasn't been banned.
body:
A few days ago, I played a game with a player who intentionally trolled our team in a ranked game after we asked them to buy a jg item at the start to which they replied that they were saving up for a different item and then proceeded to feed kills to our opponents, flame us and then mindlessly splitpushed to avoid being reported for AFKing as you can see here:

*Removed*

So because I was tilted and didn't really want to queue up again, I decided to take a look at this person's account history to see if they had a history of doing it and found that they definitely did. So I sent in a support ticket and got this response:

https://i.imgur.com/n6TIY1k.jpg

I waited a few days because I recognise that it can maybe take some time and it was possible that the player could have stopped playing for a bit and so not many reports may have come in or there may not have been much of a sample to look at. However, I checked their OP.GG this morning and came across this:

https://i.imgur.com/KkZXgPR.jpg
https://i.imgur.com/rILAMSQ.jpg
https://i.imgur.com/a4TjzUL.jpg
https://i.imgur.com/JmZXwj6.jpg
https://i.imgur.com/X1FKQi2.jpg
https://i.imgur.com/91hY0DA.jpg

There's actually so many matches between my game with them and their most recent that the game we played doesn't appear in his last 36 games shown here and there are 0 games on this account recorded on OP.GG for the last week where they haven't trolled.

To the Rioter who responded to my ticket, I'm sorry, but if you expect me or anyone else to believe that your system actually deals with intentional feeding or trolling in a reasonable manner when it's not someone hehe xding it down mid into their opponent's fountain, it's going to take a lot more than just your assurances that things will get done eventually. 

I haven't seen this player since, but there has to have been 320+ players negatively impacted by this person's gameplay since I played with them and many more before that with no discernible punishment or ban placed on the account. If that's how the system works, it's really not going to encourage anyone to take it seriously compared to what is clearly evidenced by the bans issued for chat infractions.

replies.body: Yet again more proof of Riot and their shitty banning system, too bad this post will just be seen as toxicity and not taken seriously. This is WHY we complain and protest all the time.

The system definitely isn't the best with intentionally feeding, especially with scenarios where they'll split push or something to avoid detection. Essentially it's to prevent people how are legitimately just bad from being banned for intent feeding (how much would it suck to have a few really bad games and get banned for it?). Personally I feel it would be better to turn up the detection and handle the false positives as they come but that's not my choice to make.

Support can't tell you anything about another persons account, which is why you'll always get a generic response when you send them reports, but I'll see what I can do to make sure it gets looked into.

I deleted the first screenshot because it wasn't that hard to find the guys account, and in the event that it *is* just a really really bad player, we don't want a witch hunt (hence the no naming and shaming rules for boards)

That said online moderation is always an iffy thing when it comes to laws like these.

why would you link a definition of 'volunteering' as proof? that does not prove or disprove what the law is lmao.

this is directly from the same website under Resources:

"Who can involve volunteers?

Volunteers contribute their time for no commercial gain. Only not-for-profit organisations and charities can engage volunteers in designated volunteer positions.

These organisations cover a wide range of activities and interests, such as community organisations, health (for example, hospital services and programs), welfare, sport and recreation, conservation, emergency services, environment, arts and education sectors as well as special public event involvement.

In addition to this, local government and councils run various community service programs that use volunteers such as day centres for the elderly, youth centres, children’s activities in libraries and bush regeneration activities.

Corporations and private companies (for-profit) cannot involve volunteers from outside their organisation. They can involve their own employees in volunteering projects or programs for community benefit. This is commonly referred to as ‘Corporate Volunteering’ or ‘Employee Volunteering’. Not-for-profit organisations willing, ready and able to engage with corporations can benefit greatly from this type of volunteer contribution. Volunteering NSW helps match corporate volunteers with not-for-profit organisations and volunteer opportunities."

Also if you take a look at this (too much to copy paste) https://www.fairwork.gov.au/how-we-will-help/templates-and-guides/fact-sheets/unpaid-work/unpaid-work#lawful you will see the details of it all. According to fair work (which you will notice never lists corporations as an organisation you 'volunteer' for) this is unlawful. Even if they started calling themselves 'interns' it would be unlawful. The law is actually crystal clear but for some reason you are denying it.

You also don't seem to realise that hospitals and churches are treated differently even if they are privately owned. I did make it pretty clear that it is "corporations/private companies" which hospitals and churches generally are not considered to be. But as a side note, just because some company does it, does not prove that it is legal. Might surprise you, but corporations are the biggest law breakers out there.

also they do more than just "answer questions". they are moderators, which IS a job that people get paid to do.

My bad on the first photo, thought the system in the client just changed the other players to their generic champion names after a few days but after a check, I realise that was wrong. Thanks for removing it!

Also, I know they couldn't tell me anything about the account because of privacy and a host of other reasons. The reason I made the post in the first place wasn't really centred around them not telling me about actions taken against the account merely because I was frustrated and wrote to them. It was more about how easily I could check that nothing had been done and not getting feedback on it from the IFS because it'd only send a notification to the person who last triggered the check kind of sucks. 

I'd be okay if the IFS told me about any report I'd made being involved in a decision because it's not often that I report people and it also has the placebo effect of making me feel that something actually comes of them because I only ever really see feedback on someone typing a phrase that is obviously unacceptable and getting punished almost instantly.

Thanks for the response though, this thread is more of just a frustration post because of the context of the game and the fact that I felt it was more blatant than some other games where I can see people just had a bad game but I get that no current system would handle every case perfectly.

The system definitely could be doing better here. Regardless of if he's a new/bad player or an intent feeder, he's obviously ruining a lot of games, and it's obviously not being addressed anywhere as quickly as we would like.

There is a notification the IFS gives when your report has contributed to a punishment **but** it's very limited in when it appears and not the most reliable. It's something, but personally I feel it needs to be expanded a lot to have any significant worth.

> Would be a good test of the system.

Not really. A "good test of the system" would be monitoring thousands of individuals. If you really want to know whether the system works effectively, you should put the effort in to create a list of thousands of intentional feeders, obvious and not-so obvious, monitor them for bans, and put all the data together and compare, otherwise it's just not enough to actually draw a conclusion.
